G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and the Massachusetts common law of landlord–tenant relations.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Massachusetts law implies in every residential tenancy a covenant of quiet enjoyment, which is codified in G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2 & 19.proposition: Venue is proper in the Boston Municipal Court, Dorchester Division, because the leased premises that are the subject of this action are located at 123 Ashmont Street, Dorchester, Massachusetts 02124.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant had a duty, under Massachusetts law and the applicable housing and sanitary codes, to provide Plaintiff with a habitable dwelling, including the provision of adequate and lawful heat during the winter months.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127L.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant had a duty, under Massachusetts law and the applicable housing and sanitary codes, to provide Plaintiff with a habitable dwelling, including the provision of adequate and lawful heat during the winter months.

105 C.M.R. 410.200, 410.201.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant had a duty, under Massachusetts law and the applicable housing and sanitary codes, to provide Plaintiff with a habitable dwelling, including the provision of adequate and lawful heat during the winter months.

105 C.M.R. 410.201.proposition: Pursuant to 105 C.M.R. 410.201, a Massachusetts landlord is required to maintain a heating system capable of maintaining a minimum temperature of 68°F between 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. and 64°F between 11:01 p.m. and 6:59 a.m., during the heating season.

See, e.g., Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.raw_text: See, e.g., Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994) (quiet enjoyment breaches include substantial interference with tenants’ use of premises).
See, e.g., Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.proposition: See, e.g., Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994) (quiet enjoyment breaches include substantial interference with tenants’ use of premises).
See, e.g., Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
See, e.g., Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely characterizes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment as involving serious interference with, and substantial impairment of, the tenant’s use of the leased premises, including common areas. The court explicitly states that if tenants are unable to use common areas such as sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas, that “constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.” This directly supports the proposition that quiet enjoyment breaches include substantial interference with tenants’ use of the premises.
See, e.g., Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.”

See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\.raw_text: See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–04 (1982); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. at 284.
See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from acts or omissions of the landlord that “substantially interfere with the tenant’s beneficial use of the premises.” See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–04 (1982); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. at 284.
See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the nature of “quiet enjoyment” and describes it as protecting tenants against serious interferences with the tenancy. It states that quiet enjoyment means freedom from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the premises, and that liability exists when the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s conduct is interruption of the tenant’s rights—i.e., substantial interference with beneficial use. Thus, the case supports the proposition that the covenant protects tenants from landlord acts or omissions that substantially interfere with their beneficial use of the premises.
See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … [M]ore recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: A landlord’s knowing failure to correct defective conditions that materially affect the habitability of the premises and that the landlord has reason to know will continue to interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The case holds that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment where conditions that substantially interfere with tenants’ use and enjoyment are the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, and where the landlord had the right and ability to control or correct those conditions but did not do so effectively. While the facts involve noise from a bar rather than classic habitability defects (like heat or structural issues), the court explicitly ties this to prior cases involving defective conditions (e.g., heat, boiler, services) and frames the rule in terms of nonfeasance/knowing failure to act on conditions making the premises not reasonably habitable. Thus, by analogy and reasoning, it supports the proposition, though not in those precise words.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. … Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court has recognized that violations of the State Sanitary Code and housing codes, especially those that affect essential services such as heat, can constitute a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14 and cites prior quiet-enjoyment cases, but it does not itself address State Sanitary Code or housing code violations, nor does it specifically discuss essential services such as heat. Its holding concerns whether a statutory lead paint violation, by itself and on a strict-liability basis, constitutes a § 14 violation, concluding that at least negligence and landlord notice are required. Any recognition that code-related defects can interfere with quiet enjoyment comes only indirectly through citations to other cases, not as a substantive holding here.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).”

Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 402\u.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court has recognized that violations of the State Sanitary Code and housing codes, especially those that affect essential services such as heat, can constitute a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 402\u.support_reasoning: The opinion does recognize that substantial interference with the tenants’ use and enjoyment of the apartment—here, due to rodent infestation in violation of the State Sanitary Code—constitutes a loss of property and supports liability under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment (G.L. c. 186, § 14). However, the case does not discuss heat or essential services specifically, nor does it generally address housing code or sanitary code violations as a class; its analysis is focused on rodent infestation and related conditions. Thus it supports the broader idea that serious code-violating conditions can be a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment, but not the more specific formulation about “especially those that affect essential services such as heat.”
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390, 402\u.relevant_excerpt: “There has been a substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of the apartment to which the tenants were entitled under their lease. This interference with a right guaranteed to them under their lease constitutes a loss of property to the tenants. They had a contractual right to enjoy the use of the apartment free of rodents. The judge found that the tenants withheld rent justifiably. Thus they were deprived of their contractual right by the landlord’s conduct.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–02 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Essential services such as heat are fundamental components of a habitable dwelling, and a landlord’s failure to provide adequate heat in accordance with applicable law can amount to a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely treats loss of heat and hot water as material breaches of the implied warranty of habitability, explicitly tying the landlord’s duty to provide heat and hot water to compliance with the State Sanitary Code. While the court analyzes the issue through warranty of habitability and rent abatement rather than the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, it characterizes adequate heat and hot water as essential facilities of a habitable dwelling, whose failure triggers tenant remedies. This directly supports the notion that heat is a fundamental component of habitability and that noncompliance with legal heating requirements constitutes a serious breach of the landlord’s obligations to the tenant.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Superior Court judge found…that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability… ‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’… A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable…. The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water…. The landlord can have no reasonable grounds to believe that noncompliance will be acceptable.”

Hemingway v. Brewer, 363 Mass. 184, 191\.proposition: Essential services such as heat are fundamental components of a habitable dwelling, and a landlord’s failure to provide adequate heat in accordance with applicable law can amount to a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Hemingway v. Brewer, 363 Mass. 184, 191\.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion is about implied habitability obligations measured by the State Sanitary Code and related statutes, not about the covenant of quiet enjoyment. It recognizes that statutes and the State Sanitary Code impose minimum standards for fitness for habitation, but it neither frames heat or other essential services as components of quiet enjoyment nor analyzes breach of quiet enjoyment as the relevant doctrine. The proposition links lack of heat specifically to a breach of quiet enjoyment, which this opinion does not address.
Hemingway v. Brewer, 363 Mass. 184, 191\.relevant_excerpt: "Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code ... The Code, which has the force of law and applies throughout the Commonwealth, fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation. It does so in great detail and to an extent never before incorporated in any statute. It expressly provides that '[n]o person shall ... let to another for occupancy any dwelling, dwelling unit, or rooming unit ... which does not comply' with its provisions, and further provides a criminal penalty for violation of its provisions."

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789–90 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that tenants are entitled to recover damages for such interferences, including multiple damages in appropriate cases under G.L. c. 186, § 14, as well as emotional distress and consequential damages.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and confirms that a landlord who interferes with quiet enjoyment is liable for “actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent,” but in this case the tenant did not receive a separate award of actual damages under § 14, only attorney’s fees. The court does not address emotional distress damages under § 14 in this decision (the emotional distress claim was a separate tort claim on which the tenant lost and did not appeal), nor does it award or analyze multiple damages under § 14. Thus, the case does not clearly stand as authority for the broader proposition that tenants are entitled to emotional distress and consequential damages and multiple damages under § 14.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.), provides, in pertinent part, that “any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant . . . shall ... be liable for actual and consequential damages or three month’s rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.” … On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown. On remand, Thomas is entitled to reasonable attorney’s fees on this basis.
